The geographic and sample 326 information are described in the colour schemes on the outer slot of the phylogenetic tree. 327

The initial coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak occurred in Wuhan, China 72 in late December 2019. It was caused by a new strain of beta coronavirus, known as the 73 severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) [1] [2] [3] . After the 74 identification of the first patient with COVID-19 in Japan on 15 January 2020, multiple 75 local COVID-19 clusters were identified nationwide by the end of February. The 76
Japanese government focused on identifying and mitigating emerging COVID-19 77 clusters before they could spread further. In an effort to contain these clusters and limit 78 the number of new cases, active, nationwide epidemiological surveillance of each 79 cluster was conducted in order to identify the close contacts of existing patients with 80 COVID-19. Japan has sustained a moderate spread by focusing on COVID-19 outbreak 81 clusters; however, an ever-increasing number of COVID-19 cases appeared until early 82
April, which made it difficult to identify all infection routes. 83
Although some of the COVID-19 clusters were successfully contained, the number of 84 cases continued to increase. As of 16 April, the Japanese government declared a 85 nationwide state of emergency in view of the worsening spread. To support the ongoing 86 epidemiological surveillance, we collaborated with the local public health institutes in 87 Japan (Supplementary Table S1 ) and conducted a whole genome sequencing of SARS-88
CoV-2. Our goal was to apply genomic epidemiology to predict potential routes of 89 infection within or between clusters 4 . Thus far, multiple studies have been conducted to 90 demonstrate the COVID-19 spread under nationwide and global comparative genome 91 surveillance; as of 2 June, there were already 33,483 complete genomes publicly 92 available in the Global Initiative on Sharing All Influenza Data (GISAID) platform 5 . 93 Some detailed reports have been conducted to highlight regional specific clusters and its 94 intra-and international spreads in the US 6 , UK 7 , Hungary 8 , Australia 9 , Denmark 10 , 95
Iceland 11 , and California 12 96
In this study, we aimed to evaluate viral genome sequences from COVID-19 cases until 97 early April and characterise the genealogical networks to demonstrate possible routes of 98 spread in Japan. 99

Whole genome sequences of SARS-CoV-2 were obtained by means of the PrimalSeq 118 protocol for enriching the cDNA of the SARS-CoV-2 genome using multiplex RT-PCR, 119 as proposed by the Wellcome Trust ARTIC Network 15 . We found two amplicons that 120 regularly showed low to zero coverage due to primer dimerization as described by 121
Itokawa et al. 16 . Therefore, we have modified the ARTIC Network's protocol for SARS-122
CoV-2 genome sequencing by replacing some primers for the multiplex PCR 17 . The PCR 123 products in pool 1 and 2 from the same clinical sample were pooled, purified, and 124 subjected to Illumina library construction using a QIAseq FX DNA Library Kit (QIAGEN, 125
Hilden Germany). NextSeq 500 platform (Illumina, San Diego, CA) was used for 126 sequencing the indexed libraries. The next-generation sequencing (NGS) reads were 127 mapped to the SARS-CoV-2 Wuhan-Hu-1 reference genome sequence (29.9 kb ss-RNA; 128
GenBank ID: MN908947), resulting in the specimen-specific SARS-CoV-2 genome 129 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. (which was not certified by peer review)
The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted July 2, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.07.01.20143958 doi: medRxiv preprint sequence by fully mapping on the reference. These mapped reads of SARS-CoV-2 130 sequences were assembled using A5-miseq v.20140604 18 to determine the full genome 131 sequence (Supplementary Table S2 ). The single nucleotide variations (SNV) sites and 132 marked heterogeneity were extracted by the read-mapping at ≥10× depth and from 99 -133 29796 nt region of Wuhan-Hu-1 genome sequence. 134 135

section_title: Comparative genome sequence and SNV analyses 136
text: The nearly full-length genome sequence (≥ 29 kb) of SARS-CoV-2 was retrieved from 137 the GISAID EpiCoV database in 28 April 2020, followed by multiple alignment using 138 Haplotype Explorer allows for the analysis of network graphs spatiotemporally by 156 searching and filtering nodes interactively according to meta-data (e.g., collection date, 157 location, and accession number). Over 100 network graph images were captured daily 158 from the initial detection of SARS-CoV-2 (Wuhan-Hu-1; 31 December 2019) to 16 April, 159 . We explored the relationships between outdoor activity, daily COVID-19 cases, and local 165 stay-at-home/shelter-in-place order/self-restraint campaigns in Japan, the USA (for New 166
York city and San Francisco Bay area), and the UK. The data shows population mobility 167 normalised to the value of 13 January 2020, which were retrieved from the COVID-19 168 mobility report provided by Apple (the data is available for a limited time only) 21
The funding agencies had no role in the study design, data collection or analysis, decision 177 to publish, or manuscript preparation. 178 179

The nearly full-length genome sequences (≥ 29 kb, 2,887 entries) of SARS-CoV-2 were 181 retrieved from the GISAID EpiCoV database (collection by April 16, 2020; submitted by 182
April 27, 2020) 5 . We determined the full genome sequences using 435 clinical specimens 183 in Japan collected until April 6, followed by performing a maximum-likelihood (ML) 184 phylogenetic analysis using genome-wide SNVs to trace potential infection routes (Fig.  185   1) . After the identification of the first COVID-19 case in Japan on 15 January 2020, 186 multiple local COVID-19 clusters were observed. The genome sequences of Japanese 187 isolates were assigned based on phylogeny to China isolates from late February, but 188 nationwide dissemination seemed to already be present based on the ML phylogeny (Fig.  189 1). At least 4 or 5 main clusters are observed on the ML phylogeny, but this was not 190 . On the other hand, increased mobility in the USA and UK continued through early March, 252 possibly leading to a sharp increase in COVID-19 cases from mid-March (Fig. 3B) . 253
Intriguingly, activity in the San Francisco Bay area slowed down earlier than in New 254 York; the additional 3 days taken by New York to implement stay-at-home/shelter-in-255
place orders compared to San Francisco may explain the mitigated COVID-19 spread in 256 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The new sequences have been deposited in Global Initiative on Sharing All Influenza 269 Data (GISAID) with accession IDs EPI_ISL_479792 to EPI_ISL_480227 (Table S2) .
